persona.name: EGLAMOUR
persona.alias: Agent for Silvia in her escape.

scene.title: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus: Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits. Were't not affection chains thy tender days To the sweet glances of thy honour'd love, I rather would entreat thy company To see the wonders of the world abroad, Than, living dully sluggardized at home, Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness. But since thou lovest, love still and thrive therein, Even as I would when I to love begin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adieu! Think on thy Proteus, when thou haply seest Some rare note-worthy object in thy travel: Wish me partaker in thy happiness When thou dost meet good hap; and in thy danger, If ever danger do environ thee, Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers, For I will be thy beadsman, Valentine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: And on a love-book pray for my success?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: That's on some shallow story of deep love: How young Leander cross'd the Hellespont.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: That's a deep story of a deeper love: For he was more than over shoes in love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: 'Tis true; for you are over boots in love, And yet you never swum the Hellespont.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Over the boots? nay, give me not the boots.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: No, I will not, for it boots thee not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: What?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: So, by your circumstance, I fear you'll prove.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: 'Tis love you cavil at: I am not Love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Love is your master, for he masters you: And he that is so yoked by a fool, Methinks, should not be chronicled for wise.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Yet writers say, as in the sweetest bud The eating canker dwells, so eating love Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: And writers say, as the most forward bud Is eaten by the canker ere it blow, Even so by love the young and tender wit Is turn'd to folly, blasting in the bud, Losing his verdure even in the prime And all the fair effects of future hopes. But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee, That art a votary to fond desire? Once more adieu! my father at the road Expects my coming, there to see me shipp'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Sweet Proteus, no; now let us take our leave. To Milan let me hear from thee by letters Of thy success in love, and what news else Betideth here in absence of thy friend; And likewise will visit thee with mine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: As much to you at home! and so, farewell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: He after honour hunts, I after love: He leaves his friends to dignify them more, I leave myself, my friends and all, for love. Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphosed me, Made me neglect my studies, lose my time, War with good counsel, set the world at nought; Made wit with musing weak, heart sick with thought.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Sir Proteus, save you! Saw you my master?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: But now he parted hence, to embark for Milan.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Twenty to one then he is shipp'd already, And I have play'd the sheep in losing him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Indeed, a sheep doth very often stray, An if the shepherd be a while away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: You conclude that my master is a shepherd, then, and I a sheep?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: I do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Why then, my horns are his horns, whether I wake or sleep.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: A silly answer and fitting well a sheep.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: This proves me still a sheep.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: True; and thy master a shepherd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: It shall go hard but I'll prove it by another.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: The shepherd seeks the sheep, and not the sheep the shepherd; but I seek my master, and my master seeks not me: therefore I am no sheep.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd; the shepherd for food follows not the sheep: thou for wages followest thy master; thy master for wages follows not thee: therefore thou art a sheep.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Such another proof will make me cry 'baa.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: But, dost thou hear? gavest thou my letter to Julia?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Ay sir: I, a lost mutton, gave your letter to her, a laced mutton, and she, a laced mutton, gave me, a lost mutton, nothing for my labour.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: If the ground be overcharged, you were best stick her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Nay: in that you are astray, 'twere best pound you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Nay, sir, less than a pound shall serve me for carrying your letter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: You mistake; I mean the pound,--a pinfold.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: From a pound to a pin? fold it over and over, 'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to your lover.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: But what said she?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Ay.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Nod--Ay--why, that's noddy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: You mistook, sir; I say, she did nod: and you ask me if she did nod; and I say, 'Ay.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: And that set together is noddy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Now you have taken the pains to set it together, take it for your pains.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: No, no; you shall have it for bearing the letter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Well, I perceive I must be fain to bear with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Why sir, how do you bear with me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Marry, sir, the letter, very orderly; having nothing but the word 'noddy' for my pains.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Come come, open the matter in brief: what said she?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Open your purse, that the money and the matter may be both at once delivered.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Well, sir, here is for your pains. What said she?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Truly, sir, I think you'll hardly win her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Why, couldst thou perceive so much from her?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Sir, I could perceive nothing at all from her; no, not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter: and being so hard to me that brought your mind, I fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling your mind. Give her no token but stones; for she's as hard as steel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: What said she? nothing?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: No, not so much as 'Take this for thy pains.' To testify your bounty, I thank you, you have testerned me; in requital whereof, henceforth carry your letters yourself: and so, sir, I'll commend you to my master.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
speech.text: Go, go, be gone, to save your ship from wreck, Which cannot perish having thee aboard, Being destined to a drier death on shore. I must go send some better messenger: I fear my Julia would not deign my lines, Receiving them from such a worthless post.

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: But say, Lucetta, now we are alone, Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Ay, madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Of all the fair resort of gentlemen That every day with parle encounter me, In thy opinion which is worthiest love?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Please you repeat their names, I'll show my mind According to my shallow simple skill.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: As of a knight well-spoken, neat and fine; But, were I you, he never should be mine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Lord, Lord! to see what folly reigns in us!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: How now! what means this passion at his name?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Pardon, dear madam: 'tis a passing shame That I, unworthy body as I am, Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Then thus: of many good I think him best.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Your reason?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: I have no other, but a woman's reason; I think him so because I think him so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Ay, if you thought your love not cast away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Why he, of all the rest, hath never moved me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Yet he, of all the rest, I think, best loves ye.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: His little speaking shows his love but small.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: They do not love that do not show their love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: O, they love least that let men know their love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: I would I knew his mind.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Peruse this paper, madam.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: 'To Julia.' Say, from whom?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: That the contents will show.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Say, say, who gave it thee?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Valentine's page; and sent, I think, from Proteus. He would have given it you; but I, being in the way, Did in your name receive it: pardon the fault I pray.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Now, by my modesty, a goodly broker! Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines? To whisper and conspire against my youth? Now, trust me, 'tis an office of great worth And you an officer fit for the place. Or else return no more into my sight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Will ye be gone?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: That you may ruminate.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: And yet I would I had o'erlooked the letter: It were a shame to call her back again And pray her to a fault for which I chid her. What a fool is she, that knows I am a maid, And would not force the letter to my view! Since maids, in modesty, say 'no' to that Which they would have the profferer construe 'ay.' Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love That, like a testy babe, will scratch the nurse And presently all humbled kiss the rod! How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence, When willingly I would have had her here! How angerly I taught my brow to frown, When inward joy enforced my heart to smile! My penance is to call Lucetta back And ask remission for my folly past. What ho! Lucetta!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: What would your ladyship?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Is't near dinner-time?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: I would it were, That you might kill your stomach on your meat And not upon your maid.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: What is't that you took up so gingerly?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Nothing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Why didst thou stoop, then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: To take a paper up that I let fall.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: And is that paper nothing?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Nothing concerning me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Then let it lie for those that it concerns.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Madam, it will not lie where it concerns Unless it have a false interpeter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: That I might sing it, madam, to a tune. Give me a note: your ladyship can set.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: As little by such toys as may be possible. Best sing it to the tune of 'Light o' love.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: It is too heavy for so light a tune.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Heavy! belike it hath some burden then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Ay, and melodious were it, would you sing it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: And why not you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: I cannot reach so high.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Let's see your song. How now, minion!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Keep tune there still, so you will sing it out: And yet methinks I do not like this tune.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: You do not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: No, madam; it is too sharp.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: You, minion, are too saucy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Nay, now you are too flat And mar the concord with too harsh a descant: There wanteth but a mean to fill your song.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: The mean is drown'd with your unruly bass.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Indeed, I bid the base for Proteus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me. Here is a coil with protestation! Go get you gone, and let the papers lie: You would be fingering them, to anger me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: She makes it strange; but she would be best pleased To be so anger'd with another letter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Nay, would I were so anger'd with the same! O hateful hands, to tear such loving words! Injurious wasps, to feed on such sweet honey And kill the bees that yield it with your stings! I'll kiss each several paper for amends. Look, here is writ 'kind Julia.' Unkind Julia! As in revenge of thy ingratitude, I throw thy name against the bruising stones, Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain. And here is writ 'love-wounded Proteus.' Poor wounded name! my bosom as a bed Shall lodge thee till thy wound be thoroughly heal'd; And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss. But twice or thrice was 'Proteus' written down. Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away Till I have found each letter in the letter, Except mine own name: that some whirlwind bear Unto a ragged fearful-hanging rock And throw it thence into the raging sea! Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ, 'Poor forlorn Proteus, passionate Proteus, To the sweet Julia:' that I'll tear away. And yet I will not, sith so prettily He couples it to his complaining names. Thus will I fold them one on another: Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Madam, Dinner is ready, and your father stays.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Well, let us go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: What, shall these papers lie like tell-tales here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: If you respect them, best to take them up.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Nay, I was taken up for laying them down: Yet here they shall not lie, for catching cold.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: I see you have a month's mind to them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Ay, madam, you may say what sights you see; I see things too, although you judge I wink.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
speech.text: Come, come; will't please you go?

scene.title: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Tell me, Panthino, what sad talk was that Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: 'Twas of his nephew Proteus, your son.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Why, what of him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: He wonder'd that your lordship Would suffer him to spend his youth at home, While other men, of slender reputation, Put forth their sons to seek preferment out: Some to the wars, to try their fortune there; Some to discover islands far away; Some to the studious universities. For any or for all these exercises, He said that Proteus your son was meet, And did request me to importune you To let him spend his time no more at home, Which would be great impeachment to his age, In having known no travel in his youth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Nor need'st thou much importune me to that Whereon this month I have been hammering. I have consider'd well his loss of time And how he cannot be a perfect man, Not being tried and tutor'd in the world: Experience is by industry achieved And perfected by the swift course of time. Then tell me, whither were I best to send him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: I think your lordship is not ignorant How his companion, youthful Valentine, Attends the emperor in his royal court.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: I know it well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: 'Twere good, I think, your lordship sent him thither: There shall he practise tilts and tournaments, Hear sweet discourse, converse with noblemen. And be in eye of every exercise Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: I like thy counsel; well hast thou advised: And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it, The execution of it shall make known. Even with the speediest expedition I will dispatch him to the emperor's court.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: To-morrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso, With other gentlemen of good esteem, Are journeying to salute the emperor And to commend their service to his will.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Good company; with them shall Proteus go: And, in good time! now will we break with him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Sweet love! sweet lines! sweet life! Here is her hand, the agent of her heart; Here is her oath for love, her honour's pawn. O, that our fathers would applaud our loves, To seal our happiness with their consents! O heavenly Julia!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: How now! what letter are you reading there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: May't please your lordship, 'tis a word or two Of commendations sent from Valentine, Deliver'd by a friend that came from him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Lend me the letter; let me see what news.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: There is no news, my lord, but that he writes How happily he lives, how well beloved And daily graced by the emperor; Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: And how stand you affected to his wish?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: As one relying on your lordship's will And not depending on his friendly wish.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: My will is something sorted with his wish. Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed; For what I will, I will, and there an end. I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time With Valentinus in the emperor's court: What maintenance he from his friends receives, Like exhibition thou shalt have from me. To-morrow be in readiness to go: Excuse it not, for I am peremptory.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: My lord, I cannot be so soon provided: Please you, deliberate a day or two.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Look, what thou want'st shall be sent after thee: No more of stay! to-morrow thou must go. Come on, Panthino: you shall be employ'd To hasten on his expedition.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Thus have I shunn'd the fire for fear of burning, And drench'd me in the sea, where I am drown'd. I fear'd to show my father Julia's letter, Lest he should take exceptions to my love; And with the vantage of mine own excuse Hath he excepted most against my love. O, how this spring of love resembleth The uncertain glory of an April day, Which now shows all the beauty of the sun, And by and by a cloud takes all away!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Sir Proteus, your father calls for you: He is in haste; therefore, I pray you to go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
speech.text: Why, this it is: my heart accords thereto, And yet a thousand times it answers 'no.'

scene.title: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sir, your glove.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Not mine; my gloves are on.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, then, this may be yours, for this is but one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ha! let me see: ay, give it me, it's mine: Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine! Ah, Silvia, Silvia!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How now, sirrah?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: She is not within hearing, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, sir, who bade you call her?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Your worship, sir; or else I mistook.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Well, you'll still be too forward.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Go to, sir: tell me, do you know Madam Silvia?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: She that your worship loves?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, how know you that I am in love?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms, like a malecontent; to relish a love-song, like a robin-redbreast; to walk alone, like one that had the pestilence; to sigh, like a school-boy that had lost his A B C; to weep, like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast, like one that takes diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas. You were wont, when you laughed, to crow like a cock; when you walked, to walk like one of the lions; when you fasted, it was presently after dinner; when you looked sadly, it was for want of money: and now you are metamorphosed with a mistress, that, when I look on you, I can hardly think you my master.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Are all these things perceived in me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: They are all perceived without ye.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Without me? they cannot.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Without you? nay, that's certain, for, without you were so simple, none else would: but you are so without these follies, that these follies are within you and shine through you like the water in an urinal, that not an eye that sees you but is a physician to comment on your malady.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But tell me, dost thou know my lady Silvia?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Hast thou observed that? even she, I mean.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, sir, I know her not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Dost thou know her by my gazing on her, and yet knowest her not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Is she not hard-favoured, sir?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Not so fair, boy, as well-favoured.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sir, I know that well enough.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What dost thou know?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That she is not so fair as, of you, well-favoured.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I mean that her beauty is exquisite, but her favour infinite.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That's because the one is painted and the other out of all count.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How painted? and how out of count?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Marry, sir, so painted, to make her fair, that no man counts of her beauty.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How esteemest thou me? I account of her beauty.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: You never saw her since she was deformed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How long hath she been deformed?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ever since you loved her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I have loved her ever since I saw her; and still I see her beautiful.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: If you love her, you cannot see her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Because Love is blind. O, that you had mine eyes; or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going ungartered!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What should I see then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Your own present folly and her passing deformity: for he, being in love, could not see to garter his hose, and you, being in love, cannot see to put on your hose.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Belike, boy, then, you are in love; for last morning you could not see to wipe my shoes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: True, sir; I was in love with my bed: I thank you, you swinged me for my love, which makes me the bolder to chide you for yours.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I would you were set, so your affection would cease.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Last night she enjoined me to write some lines to one she loves.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And have you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I have.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Are they not lamely writ?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No, boy, but as well as I can do them. Peace! here she comes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O excellent motion! O exceeding puppet! Now will he interpret to her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Madam and mistress, a thousand good-morrows.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O, give ye good even! here's a million of manners.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sir Valentine and servant, to you two thousand.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: He should give her interest and she gives it him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: As you enjoin'd me, I have writ your letter Unto the secret nameless friend of yours; Which I was much unwilling to proceed in But for my duty to your ladyship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I thank you gentle servant: 'tis very clerkly done.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No, madam; so it stead you, I will write Please you command, a thousand times as much; And yet--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And yet you will; and yet another 'yet.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What means your ladyship? do you not like it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Madam, they are for you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Please you, I'll write your ladyship another.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And when it's writ, for my sake read it over, And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: If it please me, madam, what then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, if it please you, take it for your labour: And so, good morrow, servant.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible, As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple! My master sues to her, and she hath taught her suitor, He being her pupil, to become her tutor. O excellent device! was there ever heard a better, That my master, being scribe, to himself should write the letter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How now, sir? what are you reasoning with yourself?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Nay, I was rhyming: 'tis you that have the reason.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: To do what?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: To be a spokesman for Madam Silvia.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: To whom?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: To yourself: why, she wooes you by a figure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What figure?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: By a letter, I should say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, she hath not writ to me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What need she, when she hath made you write to yourself? Why, do you not perceive the jest?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No, believe me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No believing you, indeed, sir. But did you perceive her earnest?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: She gave me none, except an angry word.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, she hath given you a letter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That's the letter I writ to her friend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I would it were no worse.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I'll warrant you, 'tis as well: For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty, Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply; Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover, Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover. All this I speak in print, for in print I found it. Why muse you, sir? 'tis dinner-time.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I have dined.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, but hearken, sir; though the chameleon Love can feed on the air, I am one that am nourished by my victuals, and would fain have meat. O, be not like your mistress; be moved, be moved.

scene.title: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Have patience, gentle Julia.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: I must, where is no remedy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: When possibly I can, I will return.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: If you turn not, you will return the sooner. Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Why then, we'll make exchange; here, take you this.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Sir Proteus, you are stay'd for.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Go; I come, I come. Alas! this parting strikes poor lovers dumb.

scene.title: SCENE III. The same. A street.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Nay, 'twill be this hour ere I have done weeping; all the kind of the Launces have this very fault. I have received my proportion, like the prodigious son, and am going with Sir Proteus to the Imperial's court. I think Crab, my dog, be the sourest-natured dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling, our cat wringing her hands, and all our house in a great perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed one tear: he is a stone, a very pebble stone, and has no more pity in him than a dog: a Jew would have wept to have seen our parting; why, my grandam, having no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my parting. Nay, I'll show you the manner of it. This shoe is my father: no, this left shoe is my father: no, no, this left shoe is my mother: nay, that cannot be so neither: yes, it is so, it is so, it hath the worser sole. This shoe, with the hole in it, is my mother, and this my father; a vengeance on't! there 'tis: now, sit, this staff is my sister, for, look you, she is as white as a lily and as small as a wand: this hat is Nan, our maid: I am the dog: no, the dog is himself, and I am the dog--Oh! the dog is me, and I am myself; ay, so, so. Now come I to my father; Father, your blessing: now should not the shoe speak a word for weeping: now should I kiss my father; well, he weeps on. Now come I to my mother: O, that she could speak now like a wood woman! Well, I kiss her; why, there 'tis; here's my mother's breath up and down. Now come I to my sister; mark the moan she makes. Now the dog all this while sheds not a tear nor speaks a word; but see how I lay the dust with my tears.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Launce, away, away, aboard! thy master is shipped and thou art to post after with oars. What's the matter? why weepest thou, man? Away, ass! You'll lose the tide, if you tarry any longer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: It is no matter if the tied were lost; for it is the unkindest tied that ever any man tied.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: What's the unkindest tide?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Why, he that's tied here, Crab, my dog.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the flood, and, in losing the flood, lose thy voyage, and, in losing thy voyage, lose thy master, and, in losing thy master, lose thy service, and, in losing thy service,--Why dost thou stop my mouth?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Where should I lose my tongue?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: In thy tale.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: In thy tail!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and the service, and the tied! Why, man, if the river were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears; if the wind were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Come, come away, man; I was sent to call thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Sir, call me what thou darest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Wilt thou go?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A street.
speech.text: Well, I will go.

scene.title: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

speech.stagedir: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Servant!

speech.stagedir: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Mistress?

speech.stagedir: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.

speech.stagedir: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, boy, it's for love.

speech.stagedir: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Not of you.

speech.stagedir: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Of my mistress, then.

speech.stagedir: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Twere good you knocked him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Servant, you are sad.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Indeed, madam, I seem so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Seem you that you are not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Haply I do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: So do counterfeits.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: So do you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What seem I that I am not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Wise.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What instance of the contrary?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Your folly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And how quote you my folly?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I quote it in your jerkin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: My jerkin is a doublet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Well, then, I'll double your folly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What, angry, Sir Thurio! do you change colour?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Give him leave, madam; he is a kind of chameleon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live in your air.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: You have said, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I know it well, sir; you always end ere you begin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Tis indeed, madam; we thank the giver.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Who is that, servant?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Yourself, sweet lady; for you gave the fire. Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your ladyship's looks, and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall make your wit bankrupt.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I know it well, sir; you have an exchequer of words, and, I think, no other treasure to give your followers, for it appears by their bare liveries, that they live by your bare words.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No more, gentlemen, no more:--here comes my father.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset. Sir Valentine, your father's in good health: What say you to a letter from your friends Of much good news?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: My lord, I will be thankful. To any happy messenger from thence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, my good lord, I know the gentleman To be of worth and worthy estimation And not without desert so well reputed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Hath he not a son?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, my good lord; a son that well deserves The honour and regard of such a father.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: You know him well?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I know him as myself; for from our infancy We have conversed and spent our hours together: And though myself have been an idle truant, Omitting the sweet benefit of time To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection, Yet hath Sir Proteus, for that's his name, Made use and fair advantage of his days; His years but young, but his experience old; His head unmellow'd, but his judgment ripe; And, in a word, for far behind his worth Comes all the praises that I now bestow, He is complete in feature and in mind With all good grace to grace a gentleman.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good, He is as worthy for an empress' love As meet to be an emperor's counsellor. Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me, With commendation from great potentates; And here he means to spend his time awhile: I think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Should I have wish'd a thing, it had been he.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Welcome him then according to his worth. Silvia, I speak to you, and you, Sir Thurio; For Valentine, I need not cite him to it: I will send him hither to you presently.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: This is the gentleman I told your ladyship Had come along with me, but that his mistress Did hold his eyes lock'd in her crystal looks.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Belike that now she hath enfranchised them Upon some other pawn for fealty.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Nay, then he should be blind; and, being blind How could he see his way to seek out you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself: Upon a homely object Love can wink.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Have done, have done; here comes the gentleman.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you, Confirm his welcome with some special favour.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither, If this be he you oft have wish'd to hear from.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain him To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Not so, sweet lady: but too mean a servant To have a look of such a worthy mistress.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Leave off discourse of disability: Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: My duty will I boast of; nothing else.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And duty never yet did want his meed: Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I'll die on him that says so but yourself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That you are welcome?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That you are worthless.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I wait upon his pleasure. Come, Sir Thurio, Go with me. Once more, new servant, welcome: I'll leave you to confer of home affairs; When you have done, we look to hear from you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: We'll both attend upon your ladyship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Your friends are well and have them much commended.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And how do yours?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I left them all in health.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How does your lady? and how thrives your love?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: My tales of love were wont to weary you; I know you joy not in a love discourse.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter'd now: I have done penance for contemning Love, Whose high imperious thoughts have punish'd me With bitter fasts, with penitential groans, With nightly tears and daily heart-sore sighs; For in revenge of my contempt of love, Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow. O gentle Proteus, Love's a mighty lord, And hath so humbled me, as, I confess, There is no woe to his correction, Nor to his service no such joy on earth. Now no discourse, except it be of love; Now can I break my fast, dine, sup and sleep, Upon the very naked name of love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye. Was this the idol that you worship so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No; but she is an earthly paragon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Call her divine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I will not flatter her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O, flatter me; for love delights in praises.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills, And I must minister the like to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Then speak the truth by her; if not divine, Yet let her be a principality, Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Except my mistress.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sweet, except not any; Except thou wilt except against my love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And I will help thee to prefer her too: She shall be dignified with this high honour-- To bear my lady's train, lest the base earth Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss And, of so great a favour growing proud, Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower And make rough winter everlastingly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, Valentine, what braggardism is this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Then let her alone.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Not for the world: why, man, she is mine own, And I as rich in having such a jewel As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl, The water nectar and the rocks pure gold. Forgive me that I do not dream on thee, Because thou see'st me dote upon my love. My foolish rival, that her father likes Only for his possessions are so huge, Is gone with her along, and I must after, For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But she loves you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, and we are betroth'd: nay, more, our, marriage-hour, With all the cunning manner of our flight, Determined of; how I must climb her window, The ladder made of cords, and all the means Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness. Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber, In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Go on before; I shall inquire you forth: I must unto the road, to disembark Some necessaries that I needs must use, And then I'll presently attend you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Will you make haste?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I will. Even as one heat another heat expels, Or as one nail by strength drives out another, So the remembrance of my former love Is by a newer object quite forgotten. Is it mine, or Valentine's praise, Her true perfection, or my false transgression, That makes me reasonless to reason thus? She is fair; and so is Julia that I love-- That I did love, for now my love is thaw'd; Which, like a waxen image, 'gainst a fire, Bears no impression of the thing it was. Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold, And that I love him not as I was wont. O, but I love his lady too too much, And that's the reason I love him so little. How shall I dote on her with more advice, That thus without advice begin to love her! 'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld, And that hath dazzled my reason's light; But when I look on her perfections, There is no reason but I shall be blind. If I can cheque my erring love, I will; If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.

scene.title: SCENE V. The same. A street.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Launce! by mine honesty, welcome to Milan!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am not welcome. I reckon this always, that a man is never undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a place till some certain shot be paid and the hostess say 'Welcome!'

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Come on, you madcap, I'll to the alehouse with you presently; where, for one shot of five pence, thou shalt have five thousand welcomes. But, sirrah, how did thy master part with Madam Julia?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted very fairly in jest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: But shall she marry him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: No.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: How then? shall he marry her?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: No, neither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: What, are they broken?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: No, they are both as whole as a fish.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Why, then, how stands the matter with them?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Marry, thus: when it stands well with him, it stands well with her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: What an ass art thou! I understand thee not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: What a block art thou, that thou canst not! My staff understands me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: What thou sayest?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Ay, and what I do too: look thee, I'll but lean, and my staff understands me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: It stands under thee, indeed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Why, stand-under and under-stand is all one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: But tell me true, will't be a match?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Ask my dog: if he say ay, it will! if he say no, it will; if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: The conclusion is then that it will.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: 'Tis well that I get it so. But, Launce, how sayest thou, that my master is become a notable lover?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: I never knew him otherwise.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Than how?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: A notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistakest me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Why, fool, I meant not thee; I meant thy master.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: I tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Why, I tell thee, I care not though he burn himself in love. If thou wilt, go with me to the alehouse; if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the name of a Christian.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Why?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as to go to the ale with a Christian. Wilt thou go?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. A street.
speech.text: At thy service.

scene.title: SCENE VI. The same. The DUKE'S palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. The DUKE'S palace.
speech.text: To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn; To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn; To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn; And even that power which gave me first my oath Provokes me to this threefold perjury; Love bade me swear and Love bids me forswear. O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned, Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it! At first I did adore a twinkling star, But now I worship a celestial sun. Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken, And he wants wit that wants resolved will To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better. Fie, fie, unreverend tongue! to call her bad, Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr'd With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths. I cannot leave to love, and yet I do; But there I leave to love where I should love. Julia I lose and Valentine I lose: If I keep them, I needs must lose myself; If I lose them, thus find I by their loss For Valentine myself, for Julia Silvia. I to myself am dearer than a friend, For love is still most precious in itself; And Silvia--witness Heaven, that made her fair!-- Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope. I will forget that Julia is alive, Remembering that my love to her is dead; And Valentine I'll hold an enemy, Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend. I cannot now prove constant to myself, Without some treachery used to Valentine. This night he meaneth with a corded ladder To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window, Myself in counsel, his competitor. Now presently I'll give her father notice Of their disguising and pretended flight; Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine; For Thurio, he intends, shall wed his daughter; But, Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding. Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift, As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift!

scene.title: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Counsel, Lucetta; gentle girl, assist me; And even in kind love I do conjure thee, Who art the table wherein all my thoughts Are visibly character'd and engraved, To lesson me and tell me some good mean How, with my honour, I may undertake A journey to my loving Proteus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Alas, the way is wearisome and long!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps; Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly, And when the flight is made to one so dear, Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Better forbear till Proteus make return.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: O, know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food? Pity the dearth that I have pined in, By longing for that food so long a time. Didst thou but know the inly touch of love, Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow As seek to quench the fire of love with words.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire, But qualify the fire's extreme rage, Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns. The current that with gentle murmur glides, Thou know'st, being stopp'd, impatiently doth rage; But when his fair course is not hindered, He makes sweet music with the enamell'ed stones, Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge He overtaketh in his pilgrimage, And so by many winding nooks he strays With willing sport to the wild ocean. Then let me go and hinder not my course I'll be as patient as a gentle stream And make a pastime of each weary step, Till the last step have brought me to my love; And there I'll rest, as after much turmoil A blessed soul doth in Elysium.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: But in what habit will you go along?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Not like a woman; for I would prevent The loose encounters of lascivious men: Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds As may beseem some well-reputed page.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Why, then, your ladyship must cut your hair.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: No, girl, I'll knit it up in silken strings With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots. To be fantastic may become a youth Of greater time than I shall show to be.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: What fashion, madam shall I make your breeches?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: That fits as well as 'Tell me, good my lord, What compass will you wear your farthingale?' Why even what fashion thou best likest, Lucetta.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Out, out, Lucetta! that would be ill-favour'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: A round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin, Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Lucetta, as thou lovest me, let me have What thou thinkest meet and is most mannerly. But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me For undertaking so unstaid a journey? I fear me, it will make me scandalized.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: If you think so, then stay at home and go not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Nay, that I will not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Then never dream on infamy, but go. If Proteus like your journey when you come, No matter who's displeased when you are gone: I fear me, he will scarce be pleased withal.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear: A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears And instances of infinite of love Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: All these are servants to deceitful men.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Base men, that use them to so base effect! But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles, His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate, His tears pure messengers sent from his heart, His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Pray heaven he prove so, when you come to him!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
speech.text: Now, as thou lovest me, do him not that wrong To bear a hard opinion of his truth: Only deserve my love by loving him; And presently go with me to my chamber, To take a note of what I stand in need of, To furnish me upon my longing journey. All that is mine I leave at thy dispose, My goods, my lands, my reputation; Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence. Come, answer not, but to it presently! I am impatient of my tarriance.

scene.title: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: My gracious lord, that which I would discover The law of friendship bids me to conceal; But when I call to mind your gracious favours Done to me, undeserving as I am, My duty pricks me on to utter that Which else no worldly good should draw from me. Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend, This night intends to steal away your daughter: Myself am one made privy to the plot. I know you have determined to bestow her On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates; And should she thus be stol'n away from you, It would be much vexation to your age. Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose To cross my friend in his intended drift Than, by concealing it, heap on your head A pack of sorrows which would press you down, Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care; Which to requite, command me while I live. This love of theirs myself have often seen, Haply when they have judged me fast asleep, And oftentimes have purposed to forbid Sir Valentine her company and my court: But fearing lest my jealous aim might err And so unworthily disgrace the man, A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd, I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find That which thyself hast now disclosed to me. And, that thou mayst perceive my fear of this, Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested, I nightly lodge her in an upper tower, The key whereof myself have ever kept; And thence she cannot be convey'd away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Upon mine honour, he shall never know That I had any light from thee of this.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Adieu, my Lord; Sir Valentine is coming.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Please it your grace, there is a messenger That stays to bear my letters to my friends, And I am going to deliver them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Be they of much import?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: The tenor of them doth but signify My health and happy being at your court.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Nay then, no matter; stay with me awhile; I am to break with thee of some affairs That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret. 'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I know it well, my Lord; and, sure, the match Were rich and honourable; besides, the gentleman Is full of virtue, bounty, worth and qualities Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter: Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No, trust me; she is peevish, sullen, froward, Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty, Neither regarding that she is my child Nor fearing me as if I were her father; And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers, Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her; And, where I thought the remnant of mine age Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty, I now am full resolved to take a wife And turn her out to who will take her in: Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower; For me and my possessions she esteems not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What would your Grace have me to do in this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: There is a lady in Verona here Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy And nought esteems my aged eloquence: Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor-- For long agone I have forgot to court; Besides, the fashion of the time is changed-- How and which way I may bestow myself To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words: Dumb jewels often in their silent kind More than quick words do move a woman's mind.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But she I mean is promised by her friends Unto a youthful gentleman of worth, And kept severely from resort of men, That no man hath access by day to her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, then, I would resort to her by night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe, That no man hath recourse to her by night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What lets but one may enter at her window?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground, And built so shelving that one cannot climb it Without apparent hazard of his life.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords, To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks, Would serve to scale another Hero's tower, So bold Leander would adventure it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood, Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: When would you use it? pray, sir, tell me that.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: This very night; for Love is like a child, That longs for every thing that he can come by.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But, hark thee; I will go to her alone: How shall I best convey the ladder thither?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it Under a cloak that is of any length.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, my good lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Then let me see thy cloak: I'll get me one of such another length.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak? I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me. What letter is this same? What's here? 'To Silvia'! And here an engine fit for my proceeding. I'll be so bold to break the seal for once. 'My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly, And slaves they are to me that send them flying: O, could their master come and go as lightly, Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying! My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them: While I, their king, that hither them importune, Do curse the grace that with such grace hath bless'd them, Because myself do want my servants' fortune: I curse myself, for they are sent by me, That they should harbour where their lord would be.' What's here? 'Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee.' 'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose. Why, Phaeton,--for thou art Merops' son,-- Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car And with thy daring folly burn the world? Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee? Go, base intruder! overweening slave! Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates, And think my patience, more than thy desert, Is privilege for thy departure hence: Thank me for this more than for all the favours Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee. But if thou linger in my territories Longer than swiftest expedition Will give thee time to leave our royal court, By heaven! my wrath shall far exceed the love I ever bore my daughter or thyself. Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse; But, as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And why not death rather than living torment? To die is to be banish'd from myself; And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her Is self from self: a deadly banishment! What light is light, if Silvia be not seen? What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by? Unless it be to think that she is by And feed upon the shadow of perfection Except I be by Silvia in the night, There is no music in the nightingale; Unless I look on Silvia in the day, There is no day for me to look upon; She is my essence, and I leave to be, If I be not by her fair influence Foster'd, illumined, cherish'd, kept alive. I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom: Tarry I here, I but attend on death: But, fly I hence, I fly away from life.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Soho, soho!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What seest thou?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Him we go to find: there's not a hair on's head but 'tis a Valentine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Valentine?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Who then? his spirit?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Neither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Nothing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Who wouldst thou strike?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Nothing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Villain, forbear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, sir, I'll strike nothing: I pray you,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sirrah, I say, forbear. Friend Valentine, a word.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news, So much of bad already hath possess'd them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine, For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Is Silvia dead?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No, Valentine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia. Hath she forsworn me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No, Valentine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me. What is your news?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That thou art banished--O, that's the news!-- From hence, from Silvia and from me thy friend.
