speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O, I have fed upon this woe already, And now excess of it will make me surfeit. Doth Silvia know that I am banished?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, ay; and she hath offer'd to the doom-- Which, unreversed, stands in effectual force-- A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears: Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd; With them, upon her knees, her humble self; Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them As if but now they waxed pale for woe: But neither bended knees, pure hands held up, Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears, Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire; But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die. Besides, her intercession chafed him so, When she for thy repeal was suppliant, That to close prison he commanded her, With many bitter threats of biding there.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st Have some malignant power upon my life: If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear, As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help, And study help for that which thou lament'st. Time is the nurse and breeder of all good. Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love; Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life. Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that And manage it against despairing thoughts. Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence; Which, being writ to me, shall be deliver'd Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love. The time now serves not to expostulate: Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate; And, ere I part with thee, confer at large Of all that may concern thy love-affairs. As thou lovest Silvia, though not for thyself, Regard thy danger, and along with me!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I pray thee, Launce, an if thou seest my boy, Bid him make haste and meet me at the North-gate.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I am but a fool, look you; and yet I have the wit to think my master is a kind of a knave: but that's all one, if he be but one knave. He lives not now that knows me to be in love; yet I am in love; but a team of horse shall not pluck that from me; nor who 'tis I love; and yet 'tis a woman; but what woman, I will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milkmaid; yet 'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis a maid, for she is her master's maid, and serves for wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel; which is much in a bare Christian. Here is the cate-log of her condition. 'Imprimis: She can fetch and carry.' Why, a horse can do no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only carry; therefore is she better than a jade. 'Item: She can milk;' look you, a sweet virtue in a maid with clean hands.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How now, Signior Launce! what news with your mastership?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: With my master's ship? why, it is at sea.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Well, your old vice still; mistake the word. What news, then, in your paper?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: The blackest news that ever thou heardest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, man, how black?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, as black as ink.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Let me read them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Fie on thee, jolt-head! thou canst not read.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Thou liest; I can.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Marry, the son of my grandfather.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O illiterate loiterer! it was the son of thy grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Come, fool, come; try me in thy paper.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: There; and St. Nicholas be thy speed!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Imprimis: She can milk.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, that she can.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She brews good ale.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And thereof comes the proverb: 'Blessing of your heart, you brew good ale.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She can sew.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That's as much as to say, Can she so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She can knit.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when she can knit him a stock?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She can wash and scour.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: A special virtue: for then she need not be washed and scoured.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She can spin.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Then may I set the world on wheels, when she can spin for her living.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She hath many nameless virtues.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That's as much as to say, bastard virtues; that, indeed, know not their fathers and therefore have no names.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Here follow her vices.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Close at the heels of her virtues.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She is not to be kissed fasting in respect of her breath.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That makes amends for her sour breath.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She is slow in words.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O villain, that set this down among her vices! To be slow in words is a woman's only virtue: I pray thee, out with't, and place it for her chief virtue.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She is proud.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy, and cannot be ta'en from her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She hath no teeth.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She is curst.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She will often praise her liquor.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not, I will; for good things should be praised.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She is too liberal.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she is slow of; of her purse she shall not, for that I'll keep shut: now, of another thing she may, and that cannot I help. Well, proceed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit, and more faults than hairs, and more wealth than faults.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Stop there; I'll have her: she was mine, and not mine, twice or thrice in that last article. Rehearse that once more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit,'--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: More hair than wit? It may be; I'll prove it. The cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it is more than the salt; the hair that covers the wit is more than the wit, for the greater hides the less. What's next?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'And more faults than hairs,'--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That's monstrous: O, that that were out!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: 'And more wealth than faults.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well, I'll have her; and if it be a match, as nothing is impossible,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, then will I tell thee--that thy master stays for thee at the North-gate.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: For me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: For thee! ay, who art thou? he hath stayed for a better man than thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And must I go to him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long that going will scarce serve the turn.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love letters!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; an unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into secrets! I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you, Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Since his exile she hath despised me most, Forsworn my company and rail'd at me, That I am desperate of obtaining her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: This weak impress of love is as a figure Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat Dissolves to water and doth lose his form. A little time will melt her frozen thoughts And worthless Valentine shall be forgot. How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman According to our proclamation gone?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Gone, my good lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: My daughter takes his going grievously.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: So I believe; but Thurio thinks not so. Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee-- For thou hast shown some sign of good desert-- Makes me the better to confer with thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Longer than I prove loyal to your grace Let me not live to look upon your grace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Thou know'st how willingly I would effect The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I do, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant How she opposes her against my will

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, and perversely she persevers so. What might we do to make the girl forget The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: The best way is to slander Valentine With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent, Three things that women highly hold in hate.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, if his enemy deliver it: Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Then you must undertake to slander him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do: 'Tis an ill office for a gentleman, Especially against his very friend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Where your good word cannot advantage him, Your slander never can endamage him; Therefore the office is indifferent, Being entreated to it by your friend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: You have prevail'd, my lord; if I can do it By ought that I can speak in his dispraise, She shall not long continue love to him. But say this weed her love from Valentine, It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him, Lest it should ravel and be good to none, You must provide to bottom it on me; Which must be done by praising me as much As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind, Because we know, on Valentine's report, You are already Love's firm votary And cannot soon revolt and change your mind. Upon this warrant shall you have access Where you with Silvia may confer at large; For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy, And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you; Where you may temper her by your persuasion To hate young Valentine and love my friend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: As much as I can do, I will effect: But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough; You must lay lime to tangle her desires By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ay, Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Say that upon the altar of her beauty You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart: Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears Moist it again, and frame some feeling line That may discover such integrity: For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews, Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones, Make tigers tame and huge leviathans Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands. After your dire-lamenting elegies, Visit by night your lady's chamber-window With some sweet concert; to their instruments Tune a deploring dump: the night's dead silence Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance. This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And thy advice this night I'll put in practise. Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver, Let us into the city presently To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music. I have a sonnet that will serve the turn To give the onset to thy good advice.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: About it, gentlemen!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: We'll wait upon your grace till after supper, And afterward determine our proceedings.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Even now about it! I will pardon you.

scene.title: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Fellows, stand fast; I see a passenger.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with 'em.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye: If not: we'll make you sit and rifle you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Sir, we are undone; these are the villains That all the travellers do fear so much.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: My friends,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: That's not so, sir: we are your enemies.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Peace! we'll hear him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Ay, by my beard, will we, for he's a proper man.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Then know that I have little wealth to lose: A man I am cross'd with adversity; My riches are these poor habiliments, Of which if you should here disfurnish me, You take the sum and substance that I have.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Whither travel you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: To Verona.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Whence came you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: From Milan.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Have you long sojourned there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Some sixteen months, and longer might have stay'd, If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: What, were you banish'd thence?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: I was.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: For what offence?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: For that which now torments me to rehearse: I kill'd a man, whose death I much repent; But yet I slew him manfully in fight, Without false vantage or base treachery.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Why, ne'er repent it, if it were done so. But were you banish'd for so small a fault?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Have you the tongues?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: My youthful travel therein made me happy, Or else I often had been miserable.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar, This fellow were a king for our wild faction!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: We'll have him. Sirs, a word.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Master, be one of them; it's an honourable kind of thievery.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Peace, villain!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Tell us this: have you any thing to take to?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Nothing but my fortune.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Know, then, that some of us are gentlemen, Such as the fury of ungovern'd youth Thrust from the company of awful men: Myself was from Verona banished For practising to steal away a lady, An heir, and near allied unto the duke.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: And I from Mantua, for a gentleman, Who, in my mood, I stabb'd unto the heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: And I for such like petty crimes as these, But to the purpose--for we cite our faults, That they may hold excus'd our lawless lives; And partly, seeing you are beautified With goodly shape and by your own report A linguist and a man of such perfection As we do in our quality much want--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Indeed, because you are a banish'd man, Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you: Are you content to be our general? To make a virtue of necessity And live, as we do, in this wilderness?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: What say'st thou? wilt thou be of our consort? Say ay, and be the captain of us all: We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee, Love thee as our commander and our king.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: I take your offer and will live with you, Provided that you do no outrages On silly women or poor passengers.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
speech.text: No, we detest such vile base practises. Come, go with us, we'll bring thee to our crews, And show thee all the treasure we have got, Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.

scene.title: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Already have I been false to Valentine And now I must be as unjust to Thurio. Under the colour of commending him, I have access my own love to prefer: But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy, To be corrupted with my worthless gifts. When I protest true loyalty to her, She twits me with my falsehood to my friend; When to her beauty I commend my vows, She bids me think how I have been forsworn In breaking faith with Julia whom I loved: And notwithstanding all her sudden quips, The least whereof would quell a lover's hope, Yet, spaniel-like, the more she spurns my love, The more it grows and fawneth on her still. But here comes Thurio: now must we to her window, And give some evening music to her ear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: How now, Sir Proteus, are you crept before us?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Ay, gentle Thurio: for you know that love Will creep in service where it cannot go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Ay, but I hope, sir, that you love not here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Sir, but I do; or else I would be hence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Who? Silvia?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Ay, Silvia; for your sake.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen, Let's tune, and to it lustily awhile.

speech.stagedir: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Now, my young guest, methinks you're allycholly: I pray you, why is it?

speech.stagedir: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.

speech.stagedir: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Come, we'll have you merry: I'll bring you where you shall hear music and see the gentleman that you asked for.

speech.stagedir: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: But shall I hear him speak?

speech.stagedir: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Ay, that you shall.

speech.stagedir: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: That will be music.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Hark, hark!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Is he among these?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Ay: but, peace! let's hear 'em. Who is Silvia? what is she, That all our swains commend her? Holy, fair and wise is she; The heaven such grace did lend her, That she might admired be. Is she kind as she is fair? For beauty lives with kindness. Love doth to her eyes repair, To help him of his blindness, And, being help'd, inhabits there. Then to Silvia let us sing, That Silvia is excelling; She excels each mortal thing Upon the dull earth dwelling: To her let us garlands bring.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: How now! are you sadder than you were before? How do you, man? the music likes you not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: You mistake; the musician likes me not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Why, my pretty youth?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: He plays false, father.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: How? out of tune on the strings?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Not so; but yet so false that he grieves my very heart-strings.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: You have a quick ear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Ay, I would I were deaf; it makes me have a slow heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: I perceive you delight not in music.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Not a whit, when it jars so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Hark, what fine change is in the music!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Ay, that change is the spite.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: You would have them always play but one thing?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: I would always have one play but one thing. But, host, doth this Sir Proteus that we talk on Often resort unto this gentlewoman?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: I tell you what Launce, his man, told me: he loved her out of all nick.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Where is Launce?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Gone to seek his dog; which tomorrow, by his master's command, he must carry for a present to his lady.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Peace! stand aside: the company parts.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Sir Thurio, fear not you: I will so plead That you shall say my cunning drift excels.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Where meet we?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: At Saint Gregory's well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Farewell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Madam, good even to your ladyship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: I thank you for your music, gentlemen. Who is that that spake?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: One, lady, if you knew his pure heart's truth, You would quickly learn to know him by his voice.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Sir Proteus, as I take it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Sir Proteus, gentle lady, and your servant.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: What's your will?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: That I may compass yours.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: You have your wish; my will is even this: That presently you hie you home to bed. Thou subtle, perjured, false, disloyal man! Think'st thou I am so shallow, so conceitless, To be seduced by thy flattery, That hast deceived so many with thy vows? Return, return, and make thy love amends. For me, by this pale queen of night I swear, I am so far from granting thy request That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit, And by and by intend to chide myself Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: I grant, sweet love, that I did love a lady; But she is dead.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: 'Twere false, if I should speak it; For I am sure she is not buried.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Say that she be; yet Valentine thy friend Survives; to whom, thyself art witness, I am betroth'd: and art thou not ashamed To wrong him with thy importunacy?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: And so suppose am I; for in his grave Assure thyself my love is buried.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Sweet lady, let me rake it from the earth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Go to thy lady's grave and call hers thence, Or, at the least, in hers sepulchre thine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: He heard not that.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Madam, if your heart be so obdurate, Vouchsafe me yet your picture for my love, The picture that is hanging in your chamber; To that I'll speak, to that I'll sigh and weep: For since the substance of your perfect self Is else devoted, I am but a shadow; And to your shadow will I make true love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: If 'twere a substance, you would, sure, deceive it, And make it but a shadow, as I am.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: I am very loath to be your idol, sir; But since your falsehood shall become you well To worship shadows and adore false shapes, Send to me in the morning and I'll send it: And so, good rest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: As wretches have o'ernight That wait for execution in the morn.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Host, will you go?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: By my halidom, I was fast asleep.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Pray you, where lies Sir Proteus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Marry, at my house. Trust me, I think 'tis almost day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.
speech.text: Not so; but it hath been the longest night That e'er I watch'd and the most heaviest.

scene.title: SCENE III. The same.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: This is the hour that Madam Silvia Entreated me to call and know her mind: There's some great matter she'ld employ me in. Madam, madam!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: Who calls?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: Your servant and your friend; One that attends your ladyship's command.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morrow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: As many, worthy lady, to yourself: According to your ladyship's impose, I am thus early come to know what service It is your pleasure to command me in.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: O Eglamour, thou art a gentleman-- Think not I flatter, for I swear I do not-- Valiant, wise, remorseful, well accomplish'd: Thou art not ignorant what dear good will I bear unto the banish'd Valentine, Nor how my father would enforce me marry Vain Thurio, whom my very soul abhors. Thyself hast loved; and I have heard thee say No grief did ever come so near thy heart As when thy lady and thy true love died, Upon whose grave thou vow'dst pure chastity. Sir Eglamour, I would to Valentine, To Mantua, where I hear he makes abode; And, for the ways are dangerous to pass, I do desire thy worthy company, Upon whose faith and honour I repose. Urge not my father's anger, Eglamour, But think upon my grief, a lady's grief, And on the justice of my flying hence, To keep me from a most unholy match, Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues. I do desire thee, even from a heart As full of sorrows as the sea of sands, To bear me company and go with me: If not, to hide what I have said to thee, That I may venture to depart alone.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: Madam, I pity much your grievances; Which since I know they virtuously are placed, I give consent to go along with you, Recking as little what betideth me As much I wish all good befortune you. When will you go?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: This evening coming.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: Where shall I meet you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: At Friar Patrick's cell, Where I intend holy confession.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: I will not fail your ladyship. Good morrow, gentle lady.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same.
speech.text: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.

scene.title: SCENE IV. The same.

speech.stagedir: Enter LAUNCE, with his his Dog
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: When a man's servant shall play the cur with him, look you, it goes hard: one that I brought up of a puppy; one that I saved from drowning, when three or four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it. I have taught him, even as one would say precisely, 'thus I would teach a dog.' I was sent to deliver him as a present to Mistress Silvia from my master; and I came no sooner into the dining-chamber but he steps me to her trencher and steals her capon's leg: O, 'tis a foul thing when a cur cannot keep himself in all companies! I would have, as one should say, one that takes upon him to be a dog indeed, to be, as it were, a dog at all things. If I had not had more wit than he, to take a fault upon me that he did, I think verily he had been hanged for't; sure as I live, he had suffered for't; you shall judge. He thrusts me himself into the company of three or four gentlemanlike dogs under the duke's table: he had not been there--bless the mark!--a pissing while, but all the chamber smelt him. 'Out with the dog!' says one: 'What cur is that?' says another: 'Whip him out' says the third: 'Hang him up' says the duke. I, having been acquainted with the smell before, knew it was Crab, and goes me to the fellow that whips the dogs: 'Friend,' quoth I, 'you mean to whip the dog?' 'Ay, marry, do I,' quoth he. 'You do him the more wrong,' quoth I; ''twas I did the thing you wot of.' He makes me no more ado, but whips me out of the chamber. How many masters would do this for his servant? Nay, I'll be sworn, I have sat in the stocks for puddings he hath stolen, otherwise he had been executed; I have stood on the pillory for geese he hath killed, otherwise he had suffered for't. Thou thinkest not of this now. Nay, I remember the trick you served me when I took my leave of Madam Silvia: did not I bid thee still mark me and do as I do? when didst thou see me heave up my leg and make water against a gentlewoman's farthingale? didst thou ever see me do such a trick?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Sebastian is thy name? I like thee well And will employ thee in some service presently.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: In what you please: I'll do what I can.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: I hope thou wilt. How now, you whoreson peasant! Where have you been these two days loitering?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: And what says she to my little jewel?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Marry, she says your dog was a cur, and tells you currish thanks is good enough for such a present.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: But she received my dog?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: No, indeed, did she not: here have I brought him back again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Ay, sir: the other squirrel was stolen from me by the hangman boys in the market-place: and then I offered her mine own, who is a dog as big as ten of yours, and therefore the gift the greater.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Go get thee hence, and find my dog again, Or ne'er return again into my sight. Away, I say! stay'st thou to vex me here? A slave, that still an end turns me to shame! Sebastian, I have entertained thee, Partly that I have need of such a youth That can with some discretion do my business, For 'tis no trusting to yond foolish lout, But chiefly for thy face and thy behavior, Which, if my augury deceive me not, Witness good bringing up, fortune and truth: Therefore know thou, for this I entertain thee. Go presently and take this ring with thee, Deliver it to Madam Silvia: She loved me well deliver'd it to me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: It seems you loved not her, to leave her token. She is dead, belike?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Not so; I think she lives.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Alas!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Why dost thou cry 'alas'?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: I cannot choose But pity her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Well, give her that ring and therewithal This letter. That's her chamber. Tell my lady I claim the promise for her heavenly picture. Your message done, hie home unto my chamber, Where thou shalt find me, sad and solitary.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: How many women would do such a message? Alas, poor Proteus! thou hast entertain'd A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs. Alas, poor fool! why do I pity him That with his very heart despiseth me? Because he loves her, he despiseth me; Because I love him I must pity him. This ring I gave him when he parted from me, To bind him to remember my good will; And now am I, unhappy messenger, To plead for that which I would not obtain, To carry that which I would have refused, To praise his faith which I would have dispraised. I am my master's true-confirmed love; But cannot be true servant to my master, Unless I prove false traitor to myself. Yet will I woo for him, but yet so coldly As, heaven it knows, I would not have him speed. Gentlewoman, good day! I pray you, be my mean To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: What would you with her, if that I be she?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: If you be she, I do entreat your patience To hear me speak the message I am sent on.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: From whom?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: O, he sends you for a picture.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Ay, madam.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Ursula, bring my picture here. Go give your master this: tell him from me, One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget, Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Madam, please you peruse this letter.-- Pardon me, madam; I have unadvised Deliver'd you a paper that I should not: This is the letter to your ladyship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: I pray thee, let me look on that again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: It may not be; good madam, pardon me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: There, hold! I will not look upon your master's lines: I know they are stuff'd with protestations And full of new-found oaths; which he will break As easily as I do tear his paper.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: The more shame for him that he sends it me; For I have heard him say a thousand times His Julia gave it him at his departure. Though his false finger have profaned the ring, Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: She thanks you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: What say'st thou?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: I thank you, madam, that you tender her. Poor gentlewoman! my master wrongs her much.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Dost thou know her?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Almost as well as I do know myself: To think upon her woes I do protest That I have wept a hundred several times.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: I think she doth; and that's her cause of sorrow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: Is she not passing fair?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: She hath been fairer, madam, than she is: When she did think my master loved her well, She, in my judgment, was as fair as you: But since she did neglect her looking-glass And threw her sun-expelling mask away, The air hath starved the roses in her cheeks And pinch'd the lily-tincture of her face, That now she is become as black as I.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: How tall was she?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: About my stature; for at Pentecost, When all our pageants of delight were play'd, Our youth got me to play the woman's part, And I was trimm'd in Madam Julia's gown, Which served me as fit, by all men's judgments, As if the garment had been made for me: Therefore I know she is about my height. And at that time I made her weep agood, For I did play a lamentable part: Madam, 'twas Ariadne passioning For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight; Which I so lively acted with my tears That my poor mistress, moved therewithal, Wept bitterly; and would I might be dead If I in thought felt not her very sorrow!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: She is beholding to thee, gentle youth. Alas, poor lady, desolate and left! I weep myself to think upon thy words. Here, youth, there is my purse; I give thee this For thy sweet mistress' sake, because thou lovest her. Farewell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same.
speech.text: And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her. A virtuous gentlewoman, mild and beautiful I hope my master's suit will be but cold, Since she respects my mistress' love so much. Alas, how love can trifle with itself! Here is her picture: let me see; I think, If I had such a tire, this face of mine Were full as lovely as is this of hers: And yet the painter flatter'd her a little, Unless I flatter with myself too much. Her hair is auburn, mine is perfect yellow: If that be all the difference in his love, I'll get me such a colour'd periwig. Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine: Ay, but her forehead's low, and mine's as high. What should it be that he respects in her But I can make respective in myself, If this fond Love were not a blinded god? Come, shadow, come and take this shadow up, For 'tis thy rival. O thou senseless form, Thou shalt be worshipp'd, kiss'd, loved and adored! And, were there sense in his idolatry, My substance should be statue in thy stead. I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake, That used me so; or else, by Jove I vow, I should have scratch'd out your unseeing eyes To make my master out of love with thee!

scene.title: SCENE I. Milan. An abbey.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. An abbey.
speech.text: The sun begins to gild the western sky; And now it is about the very hour That Silvia, at Friar Patrick's cell, should meet me. She will not fail, for lovers break not hours, Unless it be to come before their time; So much they spur their expedition. See where she comes. Lady, a happy evening!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. An abbey.
speech.text: Amen, amen! Go on, good Eglamour, Out at the postern by the abbey-wall: I fear I am attended by some spies.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Milan. An abbey.
speech.text: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off; If we recover that, we are sure enough.

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O, sir, I find her milder than she was; And yet she takes exceptions at your person.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What, that my leg is too long?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: No; that it is too little.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: I'll wear a boot, to make it somewhat rounder.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But love will not be spurr'd to what it loathes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What says she to my face?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: She says it is a fair one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Nay then, the wanton lies; my face is black.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But pearls are fair; and the old saying is, Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies' eyes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How likes she my discourse?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Ill, when you talk of war.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But well, when I discourse of love and peace?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What says she to my valour?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: What says she to my birth?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That you are well derived.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: True; from a gentleman to a fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Considers she my possessions?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: O, ay; and pities them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Wherefore?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That such an ass should owe them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: That they are out by lease.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Here comes the duke.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: How now, Sir Proteus! how now, Thurio! Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Not I.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Nor I.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Saw you my daughter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Neither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why then, She's fled unto that peasant Valentine; And Eglamour is in her company. 'Tis true; for Friar Laurence met them both, As he in penance wander'd through the forest; Him he knew well, and guess'd that it was she, But, being mask'd, he was not sure of it; Besides, she did intend confession At Patrick's cell this even; and there she was not; These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence. Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse, But mount you presently and meet with me Upon the rising of the mountain-foot That leads towards Mantua, whither they are fled: Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl, That flies her fortune when it follows her. I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour Than for the love of reckless Silvia.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And I will follow, more for Silvia's love Than hate of Eglamour that goes with her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: And I will follow, more to cross that love Than hate for Silvia that is gone for love.

scene.title: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.
speech.text: Come, come, Be patient; we must bring you to our captain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.
speech.text: A thousand more mischances than this one Have learn'd me how to brook this patiently.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.
speech.text: Come, bring her away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.
speech.text: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.
SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.
speech.text: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave: Fear not; he bears an honourable mind, And will not use a woman lawlessly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.
speech.text: O Valentine, this I endure for thee!

scene.title: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: How use doth breed a habit in a man! This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods, I better brook than flourishing peopled towns: Here can I sit alone, unseen of any, And to the nightingale's complaining notes Tune my distresses and record my woes. O thou that dost inhabit in my breast, Leave not the mansion so long tenantless, Lest, growing ruinous, the building fall And leave no memory of what it was! Repair me with thy presence, Silvia; Thou gentle nymph, cherish thy forlorn swain! What halloing and what stir is this to-day? These are my mates, that make their wills their law, Have some unhappy passenger in chase. They love me well; yet I have much to do To keep them from uncivil outrages. Withdraw thee, Valentine: who's this comes here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Madam, this service I have done for you, Though you respect not aught your servant doth, To hazard life and rescue you from him That would have forced your honour and your love; Vouchsafe me, for my meed, but one fair look; A smaller boon than this I cannot beg And less than this, I am sure, you cannot give.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: How like a dream is this I see and hear! Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: O miserable, unhappy that I am!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came; But by my coming I have made you happy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Had I been seized by a hungry lion, I would have been a breakfast to the beast, Rather than have false Proteus rescue me. O, Heaven be judge how I love Valentine, Whose life's as tender to me as my soul! And full as much, for more there cannot be, I do detest false perjured Proteus. Therefore be gone; solicit me no more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: What dangerous action, stood it next to death, Would I not undergo for one calm look! O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approved, When women cannot love where they're beloved!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved. Read over Julia's heart, thy first best love, For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths Descended into perjury, to love me. Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou'dst two; And that's far worse than none; better have none Than plural faith which is too much by one: Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: In love Who respects friend?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: All men but Proteus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words Can no way change you to a milder form, I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end, And love you 'gainst the nature of love,--force ye.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: O heaven!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: I'll force thee yield to my desire.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Ruffian, let go that rude uncivil touch, Thou friend of an ill fashion!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Valentine!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Thou common friend, that's without faith or love, For such is a friend now; treacherous man! Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me. Who should be trusted, when one's own right hand Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus, I am sorry I must never trust thee more, But count the world a stranger for thy sake. The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst, 'Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: My shame and guilt confounds me. Forgive me, Valentine: if hearty sorrow Be a sufficient ransom for offence, I tender 't here; I do as truly suffer As e'er I did commit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Then I am paid; And once again I do receive thee honest. Who by repentance is not satisfied Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleased. By penitence the Eternal's wrath's appeased: And, that my love may appear plain and free, All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: O me unhappy!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Look to the boy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Why, boy! why, wag! how now! what's the matter? Look up; speak.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a ring to Madam Silvia, which, out of my neglect, was never done.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Where is that ring, boy?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Here 'tis; this is it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: How! let me see: Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook: This is the ring you sent to Silvia.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: But how camest thou by this ring? At my depart I gave this unto Julia.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: And Julia herself did give it me; And Julia herself hath brought it hither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: How! Julia!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths, And entertain'd 'em deeply in her heart. How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root! O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush! Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me Such an immodest raiment, if shame live In a disguise of love: It is the lesser blot, modesty finds, Women to change their shapes than men their minds.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Than men their minds! 'tis true. O heaven! were man But constant, he were perfect. That one error Fills him with faults; makes him run through all the sins: Inconstancy falls off ere it begins. What is in Silvia's face, but I may spy More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Bear witness, Heaven, I have my wish for ever.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: And I mine.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: A prize, a prize, a prize!

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Forbear, forbear, I say! it is my lord the duke. Your grace is welcome to a man disgraced, Banished Valentine.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Sir Valentine!

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia's mine.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I; I hold him but a fool that will endanger His body for a girl that loves him not: I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: The more degenerate and base art thou, To make such means for her as thou hast done And leave her on such slight conditions. Now, by the honour of my ancestry, I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine, And think thee worthy of an empress' love: Know then, I here forget all former griefs, Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again, Plead a new state in thy unrivall'd merit, To which I thus subscribe: Sir Valentine, Thou art a gentleman and well derived; Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserved her.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: I thank your grace; the gift hath made me happy. I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake, To grant one boom that I shall ask of you.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: I grant it, for thine own, whate'er it be.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: These banish'd men that I have kept withal Are men endued with worthy qualities: Forgive them what they have committed here And let them be recall'd from their exile: They are reformed, civil, full of good And fit for great employment, worthy lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them and thee: Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts. Come, let us go: we will include all jars With triumphs, mirth and rare solemnity.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: And, as we walk along, I dare be bold With our discourse to make your grace to smile. What think you of this page, my lord?

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: What mean you by that saying?

speech.stagedir: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
speech.text: Please you, I'll tell you as we pass along, That you will wonder what hath fortuned. Come, Proteus; 'tis your penance but to hear The story of your loves discovered: That done, our day of marriage shall be yours; One feast, one house, one mutual happiness.
